thread.title: BUZZ-UK manufacturers 'overlooked' beneficiaries of a devalued yuan
thread.title_full: BUZZ-UK manufacturers 'overlooked' beneficiaries of a devalued yuan

title: BUZZ-UK manufacturers 'overlooked' beneficiaries of a devalued yuan
text:
310.50 +7.25 
** UK-listed manufacturers with cost bases in emerging Asian countries "overlooked" beneficiaries of Chinese yuan devaluation, according to Liberum 
** Market has been heavily focussed on those expected to suffer (autos, luxury, mining and industrials all cited ), but a select group of companies that manufacture in developing countries while retailing exclusively in developed countries are set to see FX upgrades 
** Yuan joins a basket of Asian currencies that have weakened against the dollar, euro and sterling in 2015. Chart: http://link.reuters.com/bah45w 
** Sports Direct has a cost of goods sold (COGS) of 56.4 pct according to Thomson Reuters data, with Liberum estimating 80-90 pct of those costs are located in Asia 
** Associated British Foods (LSE: ABF.L - news ) derives 60 pct EBIT from Primark, which has a similar manufacturing profile to Sports Direct 
** Pace (Other OTC: PCMXF - news ) outsources manufacturing to China while 82 pct revenues are in dollars 
** Tyman (Other OTC: LPUSF - news ) profits to improve by 0.5 pct for every 1 pct decrease in the yuan, broker adds 
** Stevia (Stuttgart: R02.SG - news ) producer PureCircle buys 50 pct of its raw materials from China 
** In Europe H&M preferred over Spanish rival Inditex (Amsterdam: IT6.AS - news ) 
** H&M has 75 pct of its 2,300 supplier factories located in developing Asia with a COGS of 40.6 pct - Inditex has higher proportion of manufacturing in Europe as well as a larger Chinese consumer base. Link: http://bit.ly/1mvJseU 
** US retailers Walmart Stores, Home Depot (Swiss: HD.SW - news ) , Nordstrom (NYSE: JWN - news ) and Sears all benefit on a similar theme (RM (LSE: RM.L - news ) : alasdair.pal.thomsonreuters.com@reuters.net)
